user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_io_block_set:
```c
int metal_io_block_set(struct metal_io_region *io, unsigned long offset,
	       unsigned char value, int len)
{
	unsigned char *ptr = metal_io_virt(io, offset);
	int retlen = len;

	if (!ptr)
		return -ERANGE;
	if ((offset + len) > io->size)
		len = io->size - offset;
	retlen = len;
	if (io->ops.block_set) {
		(*io->ops.block_set)(
			io, offset, value, memory_order_seq_cst, len);
	} else {
		unsigned int cint = value;
		unsigned int i;

		for (i = 1; i < sizeof(int); i++)
			cint |= ((unsigned int)value << (CHAR_BIT * i));

		for (; len && ((uintptr_t)ptr % sizeof(int)); ptr++, len--)
			*(unsigned char *)ptr = (unsigned char) value;
		for (; len >= (int)sizeof(int); ptr += sizeof(int),
						len -= sizeof(int))
			*(unsigned int *)ptr = cint;
		for (; len != 0; ptr++, len--)
			*(unsigned char *)ptr = (unsigned char) value;
		atomic_thread_fence(memory_order_seq_cst);
	}
	return retlen;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No occurrences of the Standard Library function memcmp are present in the provided code. The function performs memory writes (block set) via an ops->block_set call or manual byte/int writes; it does not perform any comparisons of null‑terminated strings. There are no calls to strcmp/strncmp/memcmp or any code that treats byte sequences as C-style null-terminated strings for comparison. Therefore, there are no fragments in this function that need investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 (do not use memcmp to compare null‑terminated strings). Note: other potential issues (e.g., pointer alignment, type-punning, atomic fences) are outside the scope of Rule 21.14 and thus not flagged here.
